conversation.message: School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I’m highly motivated to join your community and would accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately to maximize the chance of securing it. I have strong priority at School_D (2nd, behind Student_A). Student_A’s first choice is School_E, so there is a reasonable chance Student_A applies elsewhere first, giving me an opening at School_D. Even if Student_A later applies, applying now is the best way to try to lock in my top option.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re impressed by your motivation and would be happy to welcome you to our community. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_C is #2 on School_D’s true priority list (only behind Student_A) and has applied in round 1 stating School_D is their first choice and they would accept immediately. With quota 1 and no other applicants in the inbox this round, accepting now secures a very high-priority match. Waiting for Student_A is risky because Student_A ranks School_D third (after School_E and School_B) and may never apply if they match elsewhere. Therefore, accept Student_C.

conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school, and I would be excited to enroll if admitted. I’m applying because your program and environment are the best fit for my goals, and I’m ready to commit fully to contributing to the school community if accepted.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_E. Although School_E ranks me 4th (behind Student_E, Student_B, Student_A), it is still possible I could be accepted if higher-priority students apply elsewhere or are rejected. Since a match ends my search and School_E is my #1, I should apply immediately and make a clear, committed case rather than spending a round talking.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_E. After reviewing applications received this round and given our limited capacity, we’re unable to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in the rest of the process.
conversation.thought: As School_E with quota 1, my true priority list ranks Student_E #1, Student_B #2, Student_A #3, Student_D #4, Student_C #5. In this round I received [APPLY] from Student_E, Student_B, Student_A, and Student_D. Since I can accept only one and I want the highest-priority student available, I should not accept Student_D while higher-ranked candidates (E, B, A) are simultaneously applying and are willing to commit. Therefore I must reject Student_D this round to preserve the seat for a higher-priority match.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_E is my first-choice school because I’m especially interested in being part of your community and contributing academically and through activities. I would be excited to accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_E, so I should apply immediately. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd: behind Student_E and Student_B). Waiting risks Student_B applying and taking the only seat, so an early [APPLY] maximizes my chance to secure my #1 option.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_E. Given our very limited capacity and the applications received this round, we’re unable to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in the remainder of the process.
conversation.thought: School_E has quota 1 and received APPLY from Student_D, Student_A, Student_E, and Student_B. Our true priority is E > B > A > D > C, so Student_A is rank 3 among current applicants, behind Student_E and Student_B who both applied this round. Since we can only accept one and want the highest-priority feasible match, we should not accept Student_A now. Rejecting preserves capacity to accept Student_E (top choice) or Student_B (second choice). Student_A also has School_E as first choice, but that does not outweigh our own priority ordering given limited capacity and simultaneous higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions committee—I'm Student_E. I’m very interested in joining School_E and believe I would be a strong, positive contributor to the school community. I’d like to formally apply for your available seat this round.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but I have relatively low priority there (4th) and Student_B/Student_A are likely to apply and outrank me. At School_E, I am ranked #1, so an early application should secure a guaranteed match. Although School_E is my last choice, locking it in prevents ending up unmatched if higher-ranked schools fill immediately. I will apply to School_E now to secure placement.

There is no higher-priority applicant (Student_B) in my inbox this round, and accepting D secures a very strong match immediately. Given the round is early but the mechanism is binding upon acceptance, I weigh the chance of getting B later vs the risk of ending with a lower-ranked student or unfilled seat. Student_B ranks School_A last and is unlikely to apply here unless rejected elsewhere, so waiting is risky. Therefore, accept Student_D now.
